prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J0300 b6 CO(4-3) and cont
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect CO(4-3) line and 240 GHz continuum in Band 6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have configured basebands 1 and 2 to FDM mode to observe the CO(4-3) line. We centre baseband 1 at a sky frequency of 243.09 GHz, 600 MHz lower than the expected sky frequency of the CO(4-3) line based on the published redshift. We then centre baseband 2 at a sky frequency of 244.96 GHz. These two basebands combine to give us a contiguous bandwidth of 3.75 GHz (4607 km/s) to detect the CO(4-3) line. With this larger bandwidth, we reduce the chances of the line being missed or clipped off on one side due to uncertainties in the source redshift. This wider bandwidth also allows us to detect broader components or Doppler-shifted components due to possible outflows. The spectral resolution of ~9.5 km/s is sufficient for our purposes, as the line widths are expected to be of order ~1000 km/s. We have applied maximum spectral averaging to reduce the data rates. Although the rms calculated over 100km/s bandwidths is sufficient for our purposes, we retain the use of the FDM-mode, instead of switching to TDM-mode. In the event that we detect the line emission with high S/N, we can reduce the channel widths to better characterize the spectral line kinematics.
Basebands 3 and 4 have been configured to TDM mode for continuum observations, and are tuned such that we achieve the maximum possible total bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity.

We request an angular resolution of 0.9", similar to our selection in band 7 (close to the lowest possible in band 7, see Science Goal 2) to minimize biases in flux measurements due to different beam sizes. This gives us the best possible surface brightness sensitivity, while ensuring we have sufficient angular resolution to distinguish the emissions in our target from that of another source located just 1.45" away. Should the S/N be sufficiently high, we have the option of increasing the resolution using, e.g., uniform weighting, in the case that we need better spatial resolution to better discriminate between the sources. As we expect the source to be marginally resolved at most, the ACA is not required.

For the requested RMS levels of 0.2 mJy/beam over 100km/s, we expect to be able to detect molecular gas masses down to 2.4 x 10^9 solar masses/beam at 5sigma. A non-detection would constrain the gas masses down to 4 x 10^8 solar masses in a single beam. As typical starburst galaxies are expected to have gas masses of order 10^10 solar masses or greater at these scales, the requested RMS levels allow us to determine if the target is undergoing a starburst or is quiescent, which is our main science goal. As typical quasars and starburst galaxies at these high redshifts tend to have line widths of order 1000 km/s, we expect that it is sufficient to obtain the requested RMS at 100 km/s widths.
Based on the observed mid and far-IR flux densities from WISE and Spitzer/MIPs that have been published, along with model fit SEDs, we estimate that the AGN contribution to the thermal dust emission will have a flux density of ~0.15 mJy. Assuming that the emission is unresolved, we expect to be able to detect it at ~7sigma for the estimated continuum RMS of ~0.02 mJy/beam over the 7.5 GHz bandwidth. This is more than sufficient for our purposes, as the flux estimates are conservative, and assumes only an AGN component in the far-IR SEDs. If there is a starburst component in the far-IR SED, the continuum emission would be detected at larger S/N.
We have configured the correlator to the standard setup for continuum observations in this band.

We request an angular resolution of 0.9", close to the lowest possible in the most compact configurations. This gives us the best possible surface brightness sensitivity, while also enabling us to distinguish between the emissions in our target, from that of another source located just 1.45" away. If the S/N is sufficiently high, we will apply e.g., uniform weighting to achieve better angular resolutions to discriminate between the sources, if needed. As we expect the source to be marginally resolved at most, ACA is not required.
For this particular science goal, we are well aware that when ALMA is in the most compact configurations (C36-1 to C36-2), the source RA of 03hr does not coincide with the night-time LST on most days (i.e. 04hr to 20hr on March 22), where conditions are best suited for high-frequency observations. However, we believe there is a window in early March where the likelihood of observations is higher, considering that our source LST is just an hour ahead of the night-time LST on March 22. Furthermore, the total time request of 32.79 minutes (including overheads) is small, which decreases the risk involved. However, should the proposal be accepted and this science goal not be eventually observed due to such scheduling constraints, we will apply for time in Cycle 4 to complete this science goal, when the configuration schedules are reversed. The other science goals (1, 3 and 4) are not affected.

Based on the observed mid and far-IR flux densities from WISE and Spitzer/MIPs that have been published, along with model fit SEDs, we estimate that the AGN contribution to the thermal dust emission in the Rayleigh-Jeans domain will have a flux density of ~0.3 mJy. Assuming that the emission is unresolved, we expect to be able to detect it at ~5sigma for the requested RMS of ~0.06 mJy/beam. Again, the flux estimates are conservative, and if there is a starburst component in the far-IR SED, the continuum emission would be detected at larger S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1154 b4 CO(3-2)and cont
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: detect CO(3-2) line and 130 GHz continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have configured basebands 1 and 2 to FDM mode to observe the CO(4-3) line. We centre baseband 1 at a sky frequency of 138.72 GHz, 600 MHz lower than the expected sky frequency of the CO(3-2) line based on the measured redshift. We then centre baseband 2 at a sky frequency of 140.596 GHz. These two basebands combine to give us a contiguous bandwidth of 3.75 GHz (8050 km/s) to detect the CO(3-2) line. With this larger bandwidth, we reduce the risk of the line being missed or clipped off on one side due to uncertainties in the source redshift. The wider bandwidth also allows us to detect broader and Doppler-shifted components of the line due to possible outflows. The spectral resolution of ~16.8km/s is sufficient for our purposes, as the line widths are expected to be of order ~1000 km/s. We have applied maximum allowable spectral averaging to reduce the data rates. As with J0300 (Science Goal 1), we maintain use of the FDM-mode setup. In the event that the CO line is detected at high S/N, it allows us to go to better spectral resolutions to better characterize the gas kinematics.
Basebands 3 and 4 have been configured to TDM mode for continuum observations, and are tuned such that we achieve the maximum possible total bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity.

We request an angular resolution of 0.9" (similar to our selection in band 7 to minimize biases, Science Goal 4) to obtain the best possible surface brightness sensitivity, while also having sufficient angular resolution to enable us to distinguish the emissions in our target from that of another source located just ~1.6" away. If the S/N is sufficiently large, we can apply e.g., uniform weighting, to better discriminate the sources spatially if needed. As we expect the source to be marginally resolved at most, the ACA is not required.

For the requested RMS levels of 0.2 mJy/beam over 100km/s, we expect to be able to detect molecular gas masses down to 10^10 solar masses at 5sigma in a single beam. A non-detection would constrain the gas masses down to 2.5 x 10^9 solar masses/beam. As typical starburst galaxies are expected to have gas masses of order 10^10 solar masses or greater, the requested RMS levels allows us to determine if the target is undergoing a starburst or is quiescent, which is our main science goal. Should the CO line not be detected, we can integrate the spectra over larger areas in the map, to determine if there is a weak extended component just below the noise, thereby strengthening our constraints. As typical quasars and starburst galaxies at these high redshifts tend to have line widths of order 1000 km/s, we expect that it is sufficient to obtain the requested RMS at 100 km/s widths.
Based on the observed mid and far-IR flux densities from WISE and Spitzer/MIPs that have been published, along with model fit SEDs, we estimate that the AGN component of the thermal dust emission will have a flux density of ~0.02 mJy. Assuming that the emission is unresolved, we expect to be able to detect it at >3sigma for the estimated continuum RMS of ~0.016 mJy/beam over the 7.5 GHz bandwidth. This is more than sufficient for our purposes, as the flux estimates are conservative, and assumes only an AGN component in the far-IR SEDs. If there is a starburst component in the far-IR SED, the continuum emission would be detected at larger S/N.
We have configured the correlator to the standard setup for continuum observations in this band.

We request an angular resolution of 0.9", one of the lowest in the most compact configurations. This gives us the best possible surface brightness sensitivity, while ensuring we can distinguish between the emissions in our target, from that of another source located just ~ 1.6" away. Otherwise, we can increase the resolution (using ie., uniform weighting) if the S/N is sufficiently high and a slightly higher resolution is needed to better spatially resolve the sources. We expect the source to be marginally resolved at most, so the ACA is not required.

Based on the observed mid and far-IR flux densities from WISE and Spitzer/MIPs that have been published, along with model fit SEDs, we estimate that the AGN-heated thermal dust emission in the Rayleigh-Jeans domain will have a flux density of ~0.15 mJy. Assuming that the emission is unresolved, we expect to be able to detect it at ~3sigma for the requested RMS of ~0.05 mJy/beam. As the flux estimates are conservative, and assumes only an AGN-heated component in the far-IR SEDs, the 3sigma S/N is sufficient. If there is a starburst component in the far-IR SED, the continuum emission would be detected at larger S/N. A non-detection of the continuum will strongly rule out a starburst component, this being the goal of our studies.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: FeLoBAL quasars, a peculiar and rare type of quasar with strong broad iron absorption troughs, may be the missing link between starburst galaxies and normal quasars: They may be young quasars breaking out of their dense birth blanket of dusty gas after an intense starburst phase. While their host galaxies are expected to have massive young stellar components emitting intensely in the UV, our deep Hubble Space Telescope (HST) UV-optical imaging study of 4 FeLoBALs is unable to distinguish a quiescent elliptical galaxy from a heavily dust-reddened starburst. Only ALMA can provide definite proof that FeLoBALs contain starbursts. We ask to obtain CO(4-3) or CO(3-2) line maps and sub-mm continuum fluxes in 2 bands (6+7 or 4+7) for two z<1.5, optically-bright (V~17) FeLoBAL quasars with existing HST, WISE & Spitzer UV-optical and near-to-mid-IR data. Our main aim is to test if these FeLoBALs contain a lot of dust and enough molecular gas to fuel an extreme starburst. This is a modest request given that it will help settle the long-standing puzzle of the nature of these objects and test the proposed evolutionary sequence with significant implication for galaxy evolution paradigms.
